pt: {sc}empty{/sc} {sc}vacant{/sc} {sc}blank{/sc} {sc}void{/sc} {sc}vacuous{/sc} mean lacking contents which could or should be present. {sc}empty{/sc} suggests a complete absence of contents.
{sc}vacant{/sc} suggests an absence of appropriate contents or occupants.
{sc}blank{/sc} stresses the absence of any significant, relieving, or intelligible features on a surface.
{sc}void{/sc} suggests absolute emptiness as far as the mind or senses can determine.
{sc}vacuous{/sc} suggests the emptiness of a vacuum and especially the lack of intelligence or significance.

et: Middle English {it}vacaunt{/it}, borrowed from Anglo-French, borrowed from Latin {it}vacant-, vacans{/it}, present participle of {it}vacāre{/it} "to be empty or unoccupied, have space, be free,"; perhaps akin to Hittite {it}wakkāari{/it} "lacks," {it}wakšyi-{/it} "be lacking"
shortdef: not occupied by an incumbent, possessor, or officer
being without content or occupant
free from activity or work : disengaged

dt: {bc}a preparation that is administered (as by injection) to stimulate the body's {d_link|immune response|immune response} against a specific infectious agent or disease: such as

{bc}an antigenic preparation of a typically inactivated or attenuated {dx_def}see {dxt|attenuated|attenuated|2}{/dx_def} pathogenic agent (such as a bacterium or virus) or one of its components or products (such as a protein or toxin)

dt.t: Many {wi}vaccines{/wi} are made from the virus itself, either weakened or killed, which will induce antibodies to bind and kill a live virus. Measles {wi}vaccines{/wi} are just that, weakened (or attenuated) measles viruses.
… a tetanus toxoid-containing {wi}vaccine{/wi} might be recommended for wound management in a pregnant woman if [greater than or equal to] 5 years have elapsed … .
In addition the subunit used in a {wi}vaccine{/wi} must be carefully chosen, because not all components of a pathogen represent beneficial immunological targets.

aq.auth: Thomas J. Matthews and Dani P. Bolognesi

dt: {bc}a preparation of genetic material (such as a strand of synthesized {d_link|messenger RNA|messenger RNA}) that is used by the cells of the body to produce an antigenic substance (such as a fragment of virus {d_link|spike protein|spike protein})

dt.t: … Moderna's coronavirus {wi}vaccine{/wi} … works by injecting a small piece of mRNA from the coronavirus that codes for the virus' spike protein. … {phrase}mRNA vaccine{/phrase} spurs the body to produce the spike protein internally. That, in turn, triggers an immune response.

The revolutionary {phrase}messenger RNA vaccines{/phrase} that are now available have been over a decade in development. … Messenger RNA enters the cell cytoplasm and produces protein from the spike of the Covid-19 virus.

Viral {phrase}vector vaccines{/phrase}, another recent type of {wi}vaccine{/wi}, are similar to DNA and RNA {wi}vaccines{/wi}, but the virus's genetic information is housed in an attenuated virus (unrelated to the disease-causing virus) that helps to promote host cell fusion and entry.

dt: Vaccines may contain {d_link|adjuvants|adjuvant:2} (such as aluminum hydroxide) designed to enhance the strength and duration of the body's immune response.
{bc}a preparation or immunotherapy that is used to stimulate the body's immune response against noninfectious substances, agents, or diseases

dt.t: The U.S. Army is also testing a ricin {wi}vaccine{/wi} and has reported success in mice.
… many of the most promising new cancer {wi}vaccines{/wi} use dendritic cells to train the immune system to recognize tumor cells.

et: earlier, "fluid from cowpox pustules used in inoculation," noun use of {it}vaccine{/it} "of cowpox" (in the phrases {it}vaccine disease, vaccine matter{/it}), borrowed from New Latin {it}vaccina{/it} (in {it}variolae vaccinae{/it} "cowpox"), going back to Latin, feminine of {it}vaccīnus{/it} "of or from a cow," from {it}vacca{/it} "cow" (perhaps akin to Sanskrit {it}vaśā{/it} "cow") + {it}-īnus{/it} {et_link|-ine:1|-ine:1}; in extended sense, "preparation of organisms administered to produce immunity," in part borrowed from French {it}vaccin{/it}, masculine derivative of {it}vaccine{/it} "cowpox, matter from cowpox pustules," borrowed from New Latin or English
shortdef: a preparation that is administered (as by injection) to stimulate the body's immune response against a specific infectious agent or disease: such as
an antigenic preparation of a typically inactivated or attenuated pathogenic agent (such as a bacterium or virus) or one of its components or products (such as a protein or toxin)
a preparation of genetic material (such as a strand of synthesized messenger RNA) that is used by the cells of the body to produce an antigenic substance (such as a fragment of virus spike protein)

dt: {bc}the reluctance or refusal to have oneself or one's children vaccinated

dt.t: {wi}Vaccine hesitancy{/wi} can contribute to the continued spread of disease because vaccinations are not being administered.
Scientists are expressing concern over what they call "{wi}vaccine hesitancy{/wi}" regarding the COVID-19 pandemic.

WHO [World Health Organization] notes that measles cases have increased by 30 percent across the globe, and while not all cases are due to {wi}vaccine hesitancies{/wi}, some countries that had nearly eliminated the disease have seen its return.

shortdef: the reluctance or refusal to have oneself or one's children vaccinated

dt: {bc}characterized by reluctance or refusal to have oneself or one's children vaccinated

dt.t: Among the 18% of Iowans who identify as {wi}vaccine-hesitant{/wi}, about half cited uncertainty about vaccine side effects as the source of their reluctance …

shortdef: characterized by reluctance or refusal to have oneself or one's children vaccinated

dt: {bc}a physical or digital document providing proof of vaccination against one or more infectious diseases (such as COVID-19)

dt.t: Around the world, governments and other organizations are developing COVID-19 {wi}vaccine passports{/wi}—documentation to allow vaccinated people greater mobility and access to other services—to speed society's reopening and a return to ordinary life.

aq.auth: Ryan Tanner and Colleen M. Flood

dt.t: New York state is the first to issue a {wi}vaccine passport{/wi}, which people can show to obtain entry to sporting venues, concert halls and participating businesses, while the governor of Florida has banned them.

And now the push to return to a more normal life has triggered a lot of discussion about {wi}vaccine passports{/wi}, in which users can upload proof of vaccination on a smartphone app for potential entry into work, school, or other venues.

The BHA [British Horseracing Authority] is now in the process of developing a new online register of {wi}vaccine passports{/wi}. A digital database, which could be launched next year, would give authorities immediate access to the number of horses who have their jabs up to date.

shortdef: a physical or digital document providing proof of vaccination against one or more infectious diseases (such as COVID-19)

dt: {bc}a preparation that is administered (as by injection) to stimulate the body's {d_link|immune response|immune response} against a specific infectious agent or disease: such as

{bc}an antigenic preparation of a typically inactivated or attenuated {dx_def}see {dxt|attenuated|attenuated|2}{/dx_def} pathogenic agent (such as a bacterium or virus) or one of its components or products (such as a protein or toxin)

dt.t: Many {wi}vaccines{/wi} are made from the virus itself, either weakened or killed, which will induce antibodies to bind and kill a live virus. Measles {wi}vaccines{/wi} are just that, weakened (or attenuated) measles viruses.
… a tetanus toxoid-containing {wi}vaccine{/wi} might be recommended for wound management in a pregnant woman if [greater than or equal to] 5 years have elapsed … .
In addition the subunit used in a {wi}vaccine{/wi} must be carefully chosen, because not all components of a pathogen represent beneficial immunological targets.

aq.auth: Thomas J. Matthews and Dani P. Bolognesi

dt: {bc}a preparation of genetic material (such as a strand of synthesized {d_link|messenger RNA|messenger RNA}) that is used by the cells of the body to produce an antigenic substance (such as a fragment of virus {d_link|spike protein|spike protein})

dt.t: … Moderna's coronavirus {wi}vaccine{/wi} … works by injecting a small piece of mRNA from the coronavirus that codes for the virus' spike protein. … {phrase}mRNA vaccine{/phrase} spurs the body to produce the spike protein internally. That, in turn, triggers an immune response.

The revolutionary {phrase}messenger RNA vaccines{/phrase} that are now available have been over a decade in development. … Messenger RNA enters the cell cytoplasm and produces protein from the spike of the Covid-19 virus.

Viral {phrase}vector vaccines{/phrase}, another recent type of {wi}vaccine{/wi}, are similar to DNA and RNA {wi}vaccines{/wi}, but the virus's genetic information is housed in an attenuated virus (unrelated to the disease-causing virus) that helps to promote host cell fusion and entry.

dt: Vaccines may contain {d_link|adjuvants|adjuvant:2} (such as aluminum hydroxide) designed to enhance the strength and duration of the body's immune response.
{bc}a preparation or immunotherapy that is used to stimulate the body's immune response against noninfectious substances, agents, or diseases

dt.t: The U.S. Army is also testing a ricin {wi}vaccine{/wi} and has reported success in mice.
… many of the most promising new cancer {wi}vaccines{/wi} use dendritic cells to train the immune system to recognize tumor cells.

et: earlier, "fluid from cowpox pustules used in inoculation," noun use of {it}vaccine{/it} "of cowpox" (in the phrases {it}vaccine disease, vaccine matter{/it}), borrowed from New Latin {it}vaccina{/it} (in {it}variolae vaccinae{/it} "cowpox"), going back to Latin, feminine of {it}vaccīnus{/it} "of or from a cow," from {it}vacca{/it} "cow" (perhaps akin to Sanskrit {it}vaśā{/it} "cow") + {it}-īnus{/it} {et_link|-ine:1|-ine:1}; in extended sense, "preparation of organisms administered to produce immunity," in part borrowed from French {it}vaccin{/it}, masculine derivative of {it}vaccine{/it} "cowpox, matter from cowpox pustules," borrowed from New Latin or English
shortdef: a preparation that is administered (as by injection) to stimulate the body's immune response against a specific infectious agent or disease: such as
an antigenic preparation of a typically inactivated or attenuated pathogenic agent (such as a bacterium or virus) or one of its components or products (such as a protein or toxin)
a preparation of genetic material (such as a strand of synthesized messenger RNA) that is used by the cells of the body to produce an antigenic substance (such as a fragment of virus spike protein)

dt: {bc}to waver in mind, will, or feeling {bc}hesitate in choice of opinions or courses

pt: {sc}hesitate{/sc} {sc}waver{/sc} {sc}vacillate{/sc} {sc}falter{/sc} mean to show irresolution or uncertainty. {sc}hesitate{/sc} implies a pause before deciding or acting or choosing.
{sc}waver{/sc} implies hesitation after seeming to decide and so connotes weakness or a retreat.

pt.t: {it}wavered{/it} in his support of the rebels

pt: {sc}vacillate{/sc} implies prolonged hesitation from inability to reach a firm decision.

pt.t: {it}vacillated{/it} until events were out of control

pt: {sc}falter{/sc} implies a wavering or stumbling and often connotes nervousness, lack of courage, or outright fear.

et: borrowed from Latin {it}vacillātus{/it}, past participle of {it}vacillāre{/it} "to be unsteady, totter, be weak or inconstant, waver," of uncertain origin
shortdef: to waver in mind, will, or feeling : hesitate in choice of opinions or courses
to sway through lack of equilibrium
fluctuate, oscillate

dt: {bc}marked by lack of ideas or intelligence {bc}{sx|stupid||}, {sx|inane||}

pt: {sc}empty{/sc} {sc}vacant{/sc} {sc}blank{/sc} {sc}void{/sc} {sc}vacuous{/sc} mean lacking contents which could or should be present. {sc}empty{/sc} suggests a complete absence of contents.
{sc}vacant{/sc} suggests an absence of appropriate contents or occupants.
{sc}blank{/sc} stresses the absence of any significant, relieving, or intelligible features on a surface.
{sc}void{/sc} suggests absolute emptiness as far as the mind or senses can determine.
{sc}vacuous{/sc} suggests the emptiness of a vacuum and especially the lack of intelligence or significance.

shortdef: emptied of or lacking content
marked by lack of ideas or intelligence : stupid, inane
devoid of serious occupation : idle

dt: {bc}a canal in a female mammal that leads from the uterus to the external orifice of the genital canal
{bc}a canal that is similar in function or location to the vagina and occurs in various animals other than mammals

et: borrowed from New Latin, going back to Latin {it}vāgīna{/it} "scabbard, sheath," of uncertain origin

Latin {it}vāgīna{/it} as an anatomical term does not appear to be earlier than the sixteenth century, though Roman use of the word as a sexual metaphor is as old as Plautus's comedy {it}Pseudolus{/it} ({ldquo}… quom tu ibas simul, conveniebatne in vaginam tuum machaera militis?{rdquo} - {ldquo}… when you were going with him, did the soldier's sword fit in your scabbard?{rdquo}). Latin {it}vāgīna{/it} has been compared with Lithuanian {it}vóžti{/it} {ldquo}to close with a lid or cover, shut{rdquo} (from Indo-European {it}*u̯eh{inf}2{/inf}ǵ-{/it}?), though a link is doubtful given the vague sense connection and lack of other comparanda. According to Ernout and Meillet ({it}Dictionnaire étymologique de la langue latine: histoire des mots,{/it} fourth edition, 1959), {ldquo}undoubtedly a borrowed technical term{rdquo} ({ldquo}terme technique sans doute emprunté{rdquo}).
shortdef: a canal in a female mammal that leads from the uterus to the external orifice of the genital canal
a canal that is similar in function or location to the vagina and occurs in various animals other than mammals

pt: {sc}obscure{/sc} {sc}dark{/sc} {sc}vague{/sc} {sc}enigmatic{/sc} {sc}cryptic{/sc} {sc}ambiguous{/sc} {sc}equivocal{/sc} mean not clearly understandable. {sc}obscure{/sc} implies a hiding or veiling of meaning through some inadequacy of expression or withholding of full knowledge.
{sc}dark{/sc} implies an imperfect or clouded revelation often with ominous or sinister suggestion.
{sc}vague{/sc} implies a lack of clear formulation due to inadequate conception or consideration.
{sc}ambiguous{/sc} applies to language capable of more than one interpretation.
{sc}equivocal{/sc} applies to language left open to differing interpretations with the intention of deceiving or evading.

quotes.t: At the end of half an hour Tom had a {qword}vague{/qword} general idea of his lesson, but no more, for his mind was traversing the whole field of human thought, and his hands were busy with distracting recreations.
There are {qword}vague{/qword} memories in our souls of those misty centuries when the world was in its childhood.

It thrilled him with a {qword}vague{/qword} uncertain horror, to know that behind the dusky shroud, there were ghostly eyes intently fixed upon him, while he, though he stretched his own to the utmost, could see nothing but a spectral hand and one great heap of black.

When my three years of military service ended, I looked around for some way to get to spend time in rural Vietnam as a civilian. The driving force was still primarily intellectual curiosity, along with a desire to improve my language ability in a non-Western language and some {qword}vague{/qword} idea of doing folkloristic or literary studies in the future.

not clearly defined, grasped, or understood : indistinct; also : slight

dt.t: … men on foot, dressed {wi}vaguely{/wi} like janitors …
There were grants, he explained {wi}vaguely{/wi}, that had to be spent before the money went back to the federal government, so my main job was to buy lavish art books, as quickly as possible.
Where once the city was a battleground for two main militias … now at least five militias claim {wi}vaguely{/wi} defined pockets as their own.

I've always believed closers are like girlfriends: You remember the great ones, you remember the awful ones and you {wi}vaguely{/wi} remember everyone in between. (You could say the same about hockey goalies and field goal kickers.)

The driving force was still primarily intellectual curiosity, along with a desire to improve my language ability in a non-Western language and some {qword}vague{/qword} idea of doing folkloristic or literary studies in the future.

pt: {sc}obscure{/sc} {sc}dark{/sc} {sc}vague{/sc} {sc}enigmatic{/sc} {sc}cryptic{/sc} {sc}ambiguous{/sc} {sc}equivocal{/sc} mean not clearly understandable. {sc}obscure{/sc} implies a hiding or veiling of meaning through some inadequacy of expression or withholding of full knowledge.
{sc}dark{/sc} implies an imperfect or clouded revelation often with ominous or sinister suggestion.
{sc}vague{/sc} implies a lack of clear formulation due to inadequate conception or consideration.
{sc}ambiguous{/sc} applies to language capable of more than one interpretation.
{sc}equivocal{/sc} applies to language left open to differing interpretations with the intention of deceiving or evading.

quotes.t: At the end of half an hour Tom had a {qword}vague{/qword} general idea of his lesson, but no more, for his mind was traversing the whole field of human thought, and his hands were busy with distracting recreations.

dt.t: Being a religion writer, I have always tried to avoid using the Lord's name {wi}in vain{/wi}. I have not always succeeded.

pt: {sc}futile{/sc} {sc}vain{/sc} {sc}fruitless{/sc} mean producing no result. {sc}futile{/sc} may connote completeness of failure or unwisdom of undertaking.

pt.t: resistance had proved so {it}futile{/it} that surrender was the only choice left

pt: {sc}vain{/sc} usually implies simple failure to achieve a desired result.

pt.t: a {it}vain{/it} attempt to get the car started

pt: {sc}fruitless{/sc} comes close to {sc}vain{/sc} but often suggests long and arduous effort or severe disappointment.

pt.t: {it}fruitless{/it} efforts to obtain a lasting peace

quotes.t: Vanity and pride are different things, though the words are often used synonymously. A person may be proud without being {qword}vain{/qword}. Pride relates more to our opinion of ourselves, vanity to what we would have others think of us.
… the miseries of people's lives ought not to be exploited ad libitum in the furtherance of our profits or our careers, and in the {qword}vain{/qword} conviction that we understand everything.

For a half a century, scholars have searched {qword}in vain{/qword} for the source of the jade that the early civilizations of the Americas prized above all else and fashioned into precious objects of worship, trade and adornment.
Where words are scarce, they are seldom spent {qword}in vain{/qword} …
It is {qword}in vain{/qword} to say human beings ought to be satisfied with tranquillity: they must have action; and they will make it if they cannot find it.

et: Middle English {it}veyn{/it} "empty, futile, groundless, foolish, excessively proud," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}vain, vein{/it}, going back to Latin {it}vānus{/it} "lacking content, empty, illusory, marked by foolish or empty pride" {ma}{mat|wane:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: having or showing undue or excessive pride in one's appearance or achievements : conceited
marked by futility or ineffectualness : unsuccessful, useless
having no real value : idle, worthless

dt: {bc}to use (a name) profanely or without proper respect

dt.t: Numbers of clergymen have from time to time reproached me for making jokes about religion; and they have almost always invoked the authority of that very sensible commandment which says, {ldquo}Thou shalt not {wi}take{/wi} the name of the Lord thy God {wi}in vain{/wi}.{rdquo}
… I was mercifully preserved by that great God whose name they had blasphemed and {wi}taken in vain{/wi} …

shortdef: to use (a name) profanely or without proper respect

pt: {sc}valid{/sc} {sc}sound{/sc} {sc}cogent{/sc} {sc}convincing{/sc} {sc}telling{/sc} mean having such force as to compel serious attention and usually acceptance. {sc}valid{/sc} implies being supported by objective truth or generally accepted authority.
{sc}sound{/sc} implies a basis of flawless reasoning or of solid grounds.

pt.t: a {it}sound{/it} proposal for reviving the economy

pt: {sc}cogent{/sc} may stress either weight of sound argument and evidence or lucidity of presentation.

pt.t: the prosecutor's {it}cogent{/it} summation won over the jury

pt: {sc}convincing{/sc} suggests a power to overcome doubt, opposition, or reluctance to accept.
{sc}telling{/sc} stresses an immediate and crucial effect striking at the heart of a matter.

et: borrowed from Middle French or Latin; Middle French {it}valide{/it} "in good health, having legal force," borrowed from Latin {it}validus{/it} "in good health, robust, potent, having legal authority," adjective derivative from the base of {it}valēre{/it} "to have strength, be well" {ma}{mat|wield|}{/ma}
shortdef: having legal efficacy or force; especially : executed with the proper legal authority and formalities
well-grounded or justifiable : being at once relevant and meaningful
logically correct

dt: {bc}to grant official sanction to by marking
{bc}to support or corroborate on a sound or authoritative basis
{bc}to recognize, establish, or illustrate the worthiness or legitimacy of

pt: {sc}confirm{/sc} {sc}corroborate{/sc} {sc}substantiate{/sc} {sc}verify{/sc} {sc}authenticate{/sc} {sc}validate{/sc} mean to attest to the truth or validity of something. {sc}confirm{/sc} implies the removing of doubts by an authoritative statement or indisputable fact.
{sc}corroborate{/sc} suggests the strengthening of what is already partly established.

dt.t: An emotion is {wi}self-validating{/wi} when it communicates information to the self … (e.g., one feels angry because the situation is unjust and, therefore, one has good reason to be angry).
… the Pulitzer business … is a {wi}self-validating{/wi} ritual whereby journalists give each other prizes and then boast to the public about them.

dt.t: Earning that win can also feel {wi}self-validating{/wi}.

How we choose to interpret what happens in our lives—the stories we tell to ourselves and others—color how we experience life. It's time to tell a new, more accepting and {wi}self-validating{/wi} story.

pt: {sc}estimate{/sc} {sc}appraise{/sc} {sc}evaluate{/sc} {sc}value{/sc} {sc}rate{/sc} {sc}assess{/sc} mean to judge something with respect to its worth or significance. {sc}estimate{/sc} implies a judgment, considered or casual, that precedes or takes the place of actual measuring or counting or testing out.
{sc}appraise{/sc} commonly implies the fixing by an expert of the monetary worth of a thing, but it may be used of any critical judgment.
{sc}evaluate{/sc} suggests an attempt to determine relative or intrinsic worth in terms other than monetary.
{sc}value{/sc} equals {sc}appraise{/sc} but without implying expertness of judgment.

pt.t: a watercolor {it}valued{/it} by the donor at $500

pt: {sc}rate{/sc} adds to {sc}estimate{/sc} the notion of placing a thing according to a scale of values.
{sc}assess{/sc} implies a critical appraisal for the purpose of understanding or interpreting, or as a guide in taking action.

pt.t: officials are trying to {it}assess{/it} the damage

pt: {sc}appreciate{/sc} {sc}value{/sc} {sc}prize{/sc} {sc}treasure{/sc} {sc}cherish{/sc} mean to hold in high estimation. {sc}appreciate{/sc} often connotes sufficient understanding to enjoy or admire a thing's excellence.
{sc}value{/sc} implies rating a thing highly for its intrinsic worth.
{sc}prize{/sc} implies taking a deep pride in something one possesses.
{sc}treasure{/sc} emphasizes jealously safeguarding something considered precious.
{sc}cherish{/sc} implies a special love and care for something.

dt.t: a gossipy, {wi}vapid{/wi} woman, obsessed by her own elegance

pt: {sc}insipid{/sc} {sc}vapid{/sc} {sc}flat{/sc} {sc}jejune{/sc} {sc}banal{/sc} {sc}inane{/sc} mean devoid of qualities that make for spirit and character. {sc}insipid{/sc} implies a lack of sufficient taste or savor to please or interest.

pt.t: an {it}insipid{/it} romance with platitudes on every page

pt: {sc}vapid{/sc} suggests a lack of liveliness, force, or spirit.

pt.t: an exciting story given a {it}vapid{/it} treatment

pt: {sc}flat{/sc} applies to things that have lost their sparkle or zest.

pt.t: although well-regarded in its day, the novel now seems {it}flat{/it}

pt: {sc}jejune{/sc} suggests a lack of rewarding or satisfying substance.
{sc}banal{/sc} stresses the complete absence of freshness, novelty, or immediacy.
{sc}inane{/sc} implies a lack of any significant or convincing quality.

quotes.t: Waiting rooms, as I'm sure you know, are small rooms with plenty of chairs for waiting, as well as piles of old, dull magazines to read and some {qword}vapid{/qword} paintings … while you endure the boredom that doctors and dentists inflict on their patients before bringing them in to poke them and prod them and do all the miserable things that such people are paid to do.
In a secular age, symbolic rituals such as lighting the Olympic torch inevitably risk seeming a little {qword}vapid{/qword}.

… the incompetent servant, by whomsoever employed, is always against his employer. Even those born governors, noble and right honourable creatures, who have been the most imbecile in high places, have uniformly shown themselves the most opposed (sometimes in belying distrust, sometimes in {qword}vapid{/qword} insolence) to THEIR employer. What is in such wise true of the public master and servant, is equally true of the private master and servant all the world over.

et: borrowed from Latin {it}vapidus{/it} "(of wine) having lost freshness, flat"; akin to Latin {it}vappa{/it} "wine that has gone flat" and perhaps to {it}vapor{/it} "exhalation, steam" {ma}{mat|vapor:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: lacking flavor, zest, interest, animation, or spirit : flat, dull

dt.t: Just as they were among the most accomplished of all horsemen, {wi}vaqueros{/wi} were masters of the rope which they called {it}reata{/it}.
On the third day the {wi}vaqueros{/wi} brought a small herd of wild three year old colts down from the mesa and penned them …

The study, called {ldquo}Fajitas South Texas Style,{rdquo} leaves its readers with images of gringo cowboys and Mexican {wi}vaqueros{/wi} eating tough pieces of skirt steak seared directly on the hot coals of their campfires and then wrapped in tortillas.

pt: {sc}discord{/sc} {sc}strife{/sc} {sc}conflict{/sc} {sc}contention{/sc} {sc}dissension{/sc} {sc}variance{/sc} mean a state or condition marked by a lack of agreement or harmony. {sc}discord{/sc} implies an intrinsic or essential lack of harmony producing quarreling, factiousness, or antagonism.

pt.t: a political party long racked by {it}discord{/it}

pt: {sc}strife{/sc} emphasizes a struggle for superiority rather than the incongruity or incompatibility of the persons or things involved.

pt: {sc}conflict{/sc} usually stresses the action of forces in opposition but in static applications implies an irreconcilability as of duties or desires.

pt: {sc}change{/sc} {sc}alter{/sc} {sc}vary{/sc} {sc}modify{/sc} mean to make or become different. {sc}change{/sc} implies making either an essential difference often amounting to a loss of original identity or a substitution of one thing for another.

pt.t: {it}changed{/it} the shirt for a larger size

pt: {sc}alter{/sc} implies a difference in some particular respect without suggesting loss of identity.
{sc}vary{/sc} stresses a breaking away from sameness, duplication, or exact repetition.
{sc}modify{/sc} suggests a difference that limits, restricts, or adapts to a new purpose.

Celtic {it}*wasto-{/it} is generally taken to continue Indo-European {it}*upo-sth{inf}2{/inf}-o-{/it} "one who stands under," which may be correct if Gaulish {it}*wass-{/it} shares with British Celtic unrounding of {it}o{/it} in this position.

dt: {bc}very great in size, amount, degree, intensity, or especially in extent or range

pt: {sc}enormous{/sc} {sc}immense{/sc} {sc}huge{/sc} {sc}vast{/sc} {sc}gigantic{/sc} {sc}colossal{/sc} {sc}mammoth{/sc} mean exceedingly large. {sc}enormous{/sc} and {sc}immense{/sc} both suggest an exceeding of all ordinary bounds in size or amount or degree, but {sc}enormous{/sc} often adds an implication of abnormality or monstrousness.
{sc}huge{/sc} commonly suggests an immensity of bulk or amount.
{sc}gigantic{/sc} stresses the contrast with the size of others of the same kind.
{sc}colossal{/sc} applies especially to a human creation of stupendous or incredible dimensions.
{sc}mammoth{/sc} suggests both hugeness and ponderousness of bulk.

et: borrowed from Latin {it}vāstus{/it} or {it}vastus{/it} "devoid of habitation, desolate, dreary," also, "of great size, immense," probably in part continuing Indo-European {it}*h{inf}1{/inf}u̯eh{inf}2{/inf}-sto-{/it} (whence Old High German {it}wuosti{/it} "empty, deserted," Old English {it}wēste{/it}, Old Irish {it}fás{/it}), in part conflated with another base {it}*wast-{/it} of uncertain origin
shortdef: very great in size, amount, degree, intensity, or especially in extent or range

dt: {bc}to make a vain display of one's own worth or attainments {bc}{sx|brag||}
{bc}to call attention to pridefully and often boastfully

pt: {sc}boast{/sc} {sc}brag{/sc} {sc}vaunt{/sc} {sc}crow{/sc} mean to express pride in oneself or one's accomplishments. {sc}boast{/sc} often suggests ostentation and exaggeration
, but it may imply a claiming with proper and justifiable pride.

pt.t: the town {it}boasts{/it} one of the best museums in the area

pt: {sc}brag{/sc} suggests crudity and artlessness in glorifying oneself.
{sc}vaunt{/sc} usually connotes more pomp and bombast than {sc}boast{/sc} and less crudity or naïveté than {sc}brag{/sc}.
{sc}crow{/sc} usually implies exultant boasting or bragging.

shortdef: to make a vain display of one's own worth or attainments : brag
to call attention to pridefully and often boastfully

dt: {bc}to change course by turning the stern to the wind

pt: {sc}swerve{/sc} {sc}veer{/sc} {sc}deviate{/sc} {sc}depart{/sc} {sc}digress{/sc} {sc}diverge{/sc} mean to turn aside from a straight course. {sc}swerve{/sc} may suggest a physical, mental, or moral turning away from a given course, often with abruptness.
{sc}veer{/sc} implies a major change in direction.

pt.t: at that point the path {it}veers{/it} to the right

pt: {sc}deviate{/sc} implies a turning from a customary or prescribed course.
{sc}depart{/sc} suggests a deviation from a traditional or conventional course or type.
{sc}digress{/sc} applies to a departing from the subject of one's discourse.
{sc}diverge{/sc} may equal {sc}depart{/sc} but usually suggests a branching of a main path into two or more leading in different directions.

et: Middle English {it}veren{/it}, probably altered from Anglo-French {it}virer{/it} "to whirl, turn, revolve" (continental Old French, "to throw with a twisting motion"), going back to Vulgar Latin {it}*vīrāre{/it}, reduced from Latin {it}vibrāre{/it} "to wave, propel suddenly" {ma}{mat|vibrate|}{/ma}

The vowel change ({it}e{/it} in Middle English, {it}i{/it} in French) is of unclear motivation. Cf. Old Scots {it}wyr, wyre{/it} "to throw along a curving trajectory," {it}vyre{/it} "to turn about a fixed point," apparently borrowed from Anglo-French {it}virer{/it} with no alteration of vowel.
shortdef: to change direction or course
to shift in a clockwise direction
to change course by turning the stern to the wind
a change in course or direction

shortdef: to let out (something, such as a rope)

quotes.t: Cranes rise above the old rooftops, adding new office towers and new condominiums and new malls to a city where Jonathan Swift once issued his {qword}vehement{/qword} bulletins.
He cursed himself like a less scrupulous Job, as a {qword}vehement{/qword} man will do when he loses self-respect, the last mental prop under poverty.
As they shouted and mocked, I wondered how they could have developed such intense, {qword}vehement{/qword} hatred toward people with whom they had had no previous contact.

Both the ladies indulged in {qword}vehement{/qword} screaming for several minutes; and Mr. Cymon Tuggs, besides sustaining intense bodily pain, had the additional mental anguish of witnessing their distressing situation, without having the power to rescue them, by reason of his leg being firmly screwed in between the animal and the wall.

et: borrowed from Middle French, going back to Old French, borrowed from Latin {it}vehement-, vehemens, vēmens{/it} "violent, vigorous, (of feelings) overmastering, powerful," perhaps from {it}vehere{/it} "to convey, carry along, drive" + {it}-mens{/it}, adjective suffix (as in {it}clēmens{/it} "mild, calm") of uncertain origin

Alternatively explained as a prefix {it}vē-{/it} "faulty, excessive or deficient" and {it}ment-, mens{/it} "mind," in which case {it}-ehe-{/it} is an unetymological spelling of the long vowel. Though this would account for {it}vehemens{/it} in place of {it}*vehimens{/it} (with normal vowel weakening), the word never has the sense "mentally deranged" (the meanings of the presumed parallel formations {it}vēcors{/it} and {it}vēsānus{/it}).
shortdef: marked by forceful energy : powerful : such as
intensely emotional : impassioned, fervid
deeply felt

pt: {sc}old{/sc} {sc}ancient{/sc} {sc}venerable{/sc} {sc}antique{/sc} {sc}antiquated{/sc} {sc}archaic{/sc} {sc}obsolete{/sc} mean having come into existence or use in the more or less distant past. {sc}old{/sc} may apply to either actual or merely relative length of existence.
{sc}ancient{/sc} applies to occurrence, existence, or use in or survival from the distant past.
{sc}venerable{/sc} stresses the impressiveness and dignity of great age.
{sc}antique{/sc} applies to what has come down from a former or ancient time.
{sc}antiquated{/sc} implies being discredited or outmoded or otherwise inappropriate to the present time.
{sc}archaic{/sc} implies having the character or characteristics of a much earlier time.

quotes.t: [Julie] Powell never met Julia Child (who died last year), but the {qword}venerable{/qword} chef's spirit is present throughout, and Powell imaginatively reconstructs episodes from Child's life in the 1940s. Her writing is feisty and unrestrained, especially as she details killing lobsters, tackling marrowbones and cooking late into the night.

Under her stewardship, the onetime boardinghouse came to be heralded as the South's most {qword}venerable{/qword} family restaurant, a reliquary of old-fashioned cooking—collard greens enriched with fatback, creamed corn straight from the cob, fried chicken with a pepper-flecked crust—where the tables groaned beneath the weight of a quintessential midday repast, and history stood still on the plate for all to admire.
The lower the P/E, as a rough rule of thumb, the cheaper the stock. Though this guide to value has lots of exceptions, it remains a {qword}venerable{/qword} market benchmark.

I then descended to the Courts of justice, over which the judges, those {qword}venerable{/qword} sages and interpreters of the law, presided, for determining the disputed rights and properties of men, as well as for the punishment of vice, and protection of innocence.

dt: {bc}to regard with reverential respect or with admiring deference
{bc}to honor (an icon, a relic, etc.) with a ritual act of devotion

pt: {sc}revere{/sc} {sc}reverence{/sc} {sc}venerate{/sc} {sc}worship{/sc} {sc}adore{/sc} mean to honor and admire profoundly and respectfully. {sc}revere{/sc} stresses deference and tenderness of feeling.
{sc}reverence{/sc} presupposes an intrinsic merit and inviolability in the one honored and a similar depth of feeling in the one honoring.
{sc}venerate{/sc} implies a holding as holy or sacrosanct because of character, association, or age.
{sc}worship{/sc} implies homage usually expressed in words or ceremony.
{sc}adore{/sc} implies love and stresses the notion of an individual and personal attachment.

shortdef: to regard with reverential respect or with admiring deference

dt: {bc}the drawing of blood (as by {d_link|venipuncture|venipuncture}) for transfusion, {d_link|apheresis|apheresis}, diagnostic testing, or experimental procedures

Phlebotomy was once widely used to treat many types of disease but is now limited to the treatment of only a few conditions like {d_link|hemochromatosis|hemochromatosis} and {d_link|polycythemia vera|polycythemia vera}.

dt.t: While scientists struggle to understand the molecular subtleties of hemochromatosis, the clinical treatment of the disorder remains remarkably primitive: serial {wi}phlebotomy{/wi}. That is, weekly bloodletting.

shortdef: the drawing of blood (as by venipuncture) for transfusion, apheresis, diagnostic testing, or experimental procedures —called also venesection

dt: {bc}{d_link|punishment|punishment} inflicted in retaliation for an injury or offense {bc}{sx|retribution||}

dt.t: the tourists are back—{it}with a vengeance{/it}

quotes.t: He thought briefly of the long-dead woman bound to this stone in 1654 and burnt alive as a witch. And for what? An over-sharp tongue, delusions, mental eccentricity, to satisfy a private {qword}vengeance{/qword}, the need for a scapegoat in times of sickness or the failure of a harvest, or perhaps as a sacrifice to propitiate a malignant unnamed god?

Unlike the type of cannibalism much of the world had come to know—among desperate explorers, marooned sailors, and victims of famine—the Cinta Larga's consumption of human flesh was born not out of necessity but out of {qword}vengeance{/qword} and an adherence to tribal traditions and ceremony.

A holy war may be launched to root out terrorism, but its form must be a punitive crusade, an angry god's {qword}vengeance{/qword} exacted upon sinners, since no proper war can exist when there is no recognition of the other's list of grievances, no awareness of the relentless dynamic binding the powerful and powerless.

He is trying to do in his corner of Texas what death-penalty opponents say is impossible: enforce capital punishment flawlessly, ensuring that the innocent never spend a day on death row and the guilty are sent there only after trials free of bias and {qword}vengeance{/qword}.

As it turns out, police crackdowns in the 1990's did not so much destroy Los Angeles street gangs as temporarily displace them to Central America. Soon they returned with a {qword}vengeance{/qword}; gang-related homicide rose 50 percent between 1999 and 2002.

et: Middle English {it}vengeaunce{/it}, borrowed from Anglo-French, from {it}venger{/it} "to exact satisfaction for" (going back to Latin {it}vindicāre{/it} "to lay claim to, exact retribution for") + {it}-aunce{/it} {et_link|-ance|-ance} {ma}{mat|vindicate|}{/ma}
shortdef: punishment inflicted in retaliation for an injury or offense : retribution

et: Middle English {it}venim{/it}, borrowed from Anglo-French {it}venim, venyn{/it}, going back to Vulgar Latin {it}*venīmen{/it}, re-formation of Latin {it}venēmum{/it} "magical herb, poison," going back to {it}*wenes-no-m{/it}, from {it}*wenes-{/it} (whence {it}vener-, venus{/it} "sexual desire, qualities exciting desire, charm") + {it}*-no-{/it}, instrumental suffix {ma}{mat|venus|}{/ma}

pt: {sc}express{/sc} {sc}vent{/sc} {sc}utter{/sc} {sc}voice{/sc} {sc}broach{/sc} {sc}air{/sc} mean to make known what one thinks or feels. {sc}express{/sc} suggests an impulse to reveal in words, gestures, actions, or what one creates or produces.
{sc}vent{/sc} stresses a strong inner compulsion to express especially in words.
{sc}utter{/sc} implies the use of the voice not necessarily in articulate speech.
{sc}voice{/sc} does not necessarily imply vocal utterance but does imply expression or formulation in words.
{sc}broach{/sc} adds the implication of disclosing for the first time something long thought over or reserved for a suitable occasion.
{sc}air{/sc} implies an exposing or parading of one's views often in order to gain relief or sympathy or attention.

et: Middle English {it}venten{/it} "to provide with an air hole," in part verbal derivative of {it}vent{/it} "anus, outlet, {et_link|vent:2|vent:2}," in part short for {it}aventen{/it} "to cool (oneself, as by removing a helmet), release, let air out of," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}aventer{/it} "to allow to escape, release, fan," probably altered by vowel reduction from Old French {it}esventer{/it} "to fan, cool by stirring the air," going back to Vulgar Latin {it}*exventāre{/it}, from Latin {it}ex-{/it} {et_link|ex-:1|ex-:1} + {it}-ventāre{/it}, verbal derivative of {it}ventus{/it} "wind" {ma}{mat|wind:1|}{/ma}

to serve as a vent for
discharge, expel

pt: {sc}express{/sc} {sc}vent{/sc} {sc}utter{/sc} {sc}voice{/sc} {sc}broach{/sc} {sc}air{/sc} mean to make known what one thinks or feels. {sc}express{/sc} suggests an impulse to reveal in words, gestures, actions, or what one creates or produces.
{sc}vent{/sc} stresses a strong inner compulsion to express especially in words.
{sc}utter{/sc} implies the use of the voice not necessarily in articulate speech.
{sc}voice{/sc} does not necessarily imply vocal utterance but does imply expression or formulation in words.
{sc}broach{/sc} adds the implication of disclosing for the first time something long thought over or reserved for a suitable occasion.
{sc}air{/sc} implies an exposing or parading of one's views often in order to gain relief or sympathy or attention.

pt: {sc}express{/sc} {sc}vent{/sc} {sc}utter{/sc} {sc}voice{/sc} {sc}broach{/sc} {sc}air{/sc} mean to make known what one thinks or feels. {sc}express{/sc} suggests an impulse to reveal in words, gestures, actions, or what one creates or produces.
{sc}vent{/sc} stresses a strong inner compulsion to express especially in words.
{sc}utter{/sc} implies the use of the voice not necessarily in articulate speech.
{sc}voice{/sc} does not necessarily imply vocal utterance but does imply expression or formulation in words.
{sc}broach{/sc} adds the implication of disclosing for the first time something long thought over or reserved for a suitable occasion.
{sc}air{/sc} implies an exposing or parading of one's views often in order to gain relief or sympathy or attention.

et: borrowed perhaps via an Indo-Portuguese creole from Portuguese {it}varanda{/it}, akin to Spanish {it}baranda{/it} "railing" (earlier, "balcony, floor of a building"), Catalan {it}barana{/it} "railing," Old Occitan {it}baranda{/it} "barrier, barricade," all going back to {it}*varanda{/it} "enclosing barrier, the area enclosed," of obscure origin; reinforced by Hindi & Urdu {it}baraṇḍā{/it} "roofed gallery," Marathi {it}varãḍ, varãḍā{/it} "parapet," in part borrowed from Portuguese {it}varanda{/it} and English {it}veranda{/it}, in part going back to Sanskrit {it}varaṇḍaka-{/it} "mound of earth, rampart separating two fighting elephants," {it}varaṇḍa-{/it} "partition wall"

An Anglo-Indian word, most of the early evidence for which is cited in Yule and Burnell's {it}Hobson-Jobson{/it} (2nd edition 1903) and the {it}Oxford English Dictionary.{/it} The superficial similarity in form and meaning of the Romance and Indo-Aryan words is striking enough that the Romance scholar Joan Coromines attempted to connect them, positing an Indo-European substratal noun as the source of both, to which he added Lithuanian (Žemaitian dialect) {it}varanda{/it} "loop plaited from flexible twigs" ({it}Diccionario crítico etimológico castellano e hispánico{/it}). It is questionable, however, if the original meanings of the three etyma are really closely comparable, so that the phonetic likeness may simply be coincidence. The Romance word has been connected with Spanish and Portuguese {it}vara{/it} "rod, pole" and other progeny of Latin {it}vāra{/it} "forked pole," but, as Coromines points out, the deverbal suffix {it}-anda{/it} would require the existence of an otherwise unknown verb {it}*varar{/it}; other Romance forms descended from a variant {it}*varandia/varania{/it} (see Coromines) make such a hypothesis even less likely.
shortdef: a usually roofed open gallery or portico attached to the exterior of a building

The Romance word has been connected with Spanish and Portuguese {it}vara{/it} "rod, pole" and other progeny of Latin {it}vāra{/it} "forked pole," but, as Coromines points out, the deverbal suffix {it}-anda{/it} would require the existence of an otherwise unknown verb {it}*varar{/it}; other Romance forms descended from a variant {it}*varandia/varania{/it} (see Coromines) make such a hypothesis even less likely.
shortdef: a usually roofed open gallery or portico attached to the exterior of a building

pt: {sc}wordy{/sc} {sc}verbose{/sc} {sc}prolix{/sc} {sc}diffuse{/sc} mean using more words than necessary to express thought. {sc}wordy{/sc} may also imply loquaciousness or garrulity.
{sc}verbose{/sc} suggests a resulting dullness, obscurity, or lack of incisiveness or precision.
{sc}prolix{/sc} suggests unreasonable and tedious dwelling on details.

pt.t: habitually transformed brief anecdotes into {it}prolix{/it} sagas

pt: {sc}diffuse{/sc} stresses lack of compactness and pointedness of style.

pt.t: {it}diffuse{/it} memoirs that are so many shaggy-dog stories

quotes.t: What makes this tiny tome so much fun are the answers. There are occasional one-word zingers: to a {qword}verbose{/qword} question as to whether a resident of a planet with two suns would have two shadows, Merlin's response is "Yes." The longest answers are about a page in length and seem to be triggered when a questioner happens upon one of the author's favorite topics or pet peeves, such as relativity, tachyons, and the endangered ozone layer.

Something seems to have gone seriously wrong with the subediting and proof-reading of this self-indulgently {qword}verbose{/qword} and misprint-ridden production, which is further flawed by a mis-match between the author's vaulting theoretical ambitions and his scholarly limitations, notably his faulty grasp of ancient Greek and inability to deliver a clear and consistent line of reasoned and logical argument.

I must confess … that if I had known how many classics there are in English literature, and how {qword}verbose{/qword} the best of them contrive to be, I should never have undertaken the work. They only allow one seventy thousand words, you see.

shortdef: containing more words than necessary : wordy; also : impaired by wordiness
given to wordiness

dt.t: These visits … qualify as {ldquo}research{rdquo} under the convoluted regulations of the U.S. embargo and are therefore deemed legal, whereas pleasure travel is {wi}verboten{/wi}.
Same-sex marriage and gay parents, topics once {wi}verboten{/wi} in mainstream America, have become hot-buttons in this election year.
… it's easy to forget that such intercultural exchanges were once {wi}verboten{/wi}.
For a long time paisley ties were {wi}verboten{/wi} on the Jayhawk bench because Brown was wearing one when he lost his first game at Kansas five years ago.

et: borrowed from German, going back to Old High German {it}farboten{/it}, past participle of {it}farbiotan{/it} "to forbid," (parallel to Old English {it}forbēodan{/it} "to {et_link|forbid:1|forbid:1}"), from {it}far-, fur-{/it} {et_link|for-|for-} + {it}biotan{/it} "to offer" {ma}{mat|bid:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: not permitted or allowed : forbidden or prohibited by or as if by authority

dt: {bc}to use (a word and especially a noun) as a {d_link|verb|verb:1} {bc}to make (a word) into a verb

dt.t: A television announcer in Vero Beach, Fla., spoke of a promise "to upkeep the beach," thus {wi}verbing{/wi} a word that had been in use as an honest noun since 1884.

et: borrowed from Latin {it}vergere{/it} "to move downward, slope downward, sink," going back to Indo-European {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}u̯erg-{/it} "turn around, turn (to)," whence also, with varying ablaut and suffixation, Greek {it}eérgō, eérgein{/it} (Attic {it}eírgein{/it}) "to shut in, keep away, hinder" (conflated with outcomes of {it}*u̯erǵ-{/it} "shut in"), Sanskrit (Vedic) {it}vṛṇákti{/it} "(s/he) turns," and, as a nominal derivative, Hittite {it}ḫurki-{/it} "wheel"

This is the etymological solution preferred by {it}Lexikon der indogermanischen Verben,{/it} 2. Auflage, 2001, and M. de Vaan, {it}Etymological Dictionary of Latin and the Other Italic Languages{/it} (Brill, 2008). The laryngeal {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}{/it} is required by the Hittite noun, though the Greek verb then must be explained as the result of vowel assimilation ({it}*au̯erg-{/it} to {it}*eu̯erg-{/it}). See also {et_link|wrench:1|wrench:1}.

The laryngeal {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}{/it} is required by the Hittite noun, though the Greek verb then must be explained as the result of vowel assimilation ({it}*au̯erg-{/it} to {it}*eu̯erg-{/it}). See also {et_link|wrench:1|wrench:1}.

quotes.t: For the proliferation of rich {qword}vernacular{/qword} literatures in the twelfth century secured the place of the vulgar tongues in European society, and this entrenchment of the {qword}vernacular{/qword} tongues made the European peoples more conscious of being separated from each other; decreased the cosmopolitan attitudes of the European nobility; and encouraged xenophobia, which became common in the thirteenth century.
Hurricanes, fires and economic development unfortunately have caused many examples of both {qword}vernacular{/qword} and more classical architecture to disappear over the years.

Native crafts, the use of local materials, and {qword}vernacular{/qword} buildings were considered integral to each country's heritage, and their preservation and revival became part of the movement to forge a strong national identity.

While there are American operas galore, some of which are quite good indeed, there is no {qword}vernacular{/qword} opera tradition in America—instead, we have musical comedy—and now that supertitles have become standard equipment at major American opera houses, the chances that those houses will start regularly performing foreign-language operas in English translation have dropped from slim to none.

et: Latin {it}vernāculus{/it} "belonging to the household, domestic, native" (from {it}verna{/it} "slave born in the household"—of uncertain origin— + {it}-āculus{/it}, perhaps originally diminutive suffix, though derivation is unclear) + {et_link|-ar|-ar}
shortdef: using a language or dialect native to a region or country rather than a literary, cultured, or foreign language
of, relating to, or being a nonstandard language or dialect of a place, region, or country
of, relating to, or being the normal spoken form of a language

quotes.t: … the sources for [Cole] Porter's chromaticism and syncopation are the {qword}vernacular{/qword} of black music in America.
But ask baseball people about [Michael] Young, and they'll admiringly tell you that he is a "grinder," {qword}vernacular{/qword} for a player who works his butt off.

New Mexico is not the easiest region in the country for an architect to establish a practice in. It is not that the area is indifferent to architecture—it is more that the traditional south-western architectural {qword}vernacular{/qword} is so awe-inspiring that it tends to overwhelm most efforts to create a credible personal voice.

For Lu Xun helped revolutionize Chinese writing, tugging the written language toward the {qword}vernacular{/qword} so that it was easier to learn, and he even endorsed the heresy of abandoning Chinese characters for the Roman alphabet so that literacy could spread more easily.

What was required was a vagrant and a visionary, a man of mystic recklessness. The man who dared point the way would have to use the {qword}vernacular{/qword}, and not speak but shriek. Paracelsus (1493–1541) was suspect in his day, and never lost his reputation as a charlatan.

{bc}a cloth resembling the legendary one of St. Veronica

et: Middle English, borrowed from Medieval Latin, probably by false etymological parsing (as Late Latin {it}vēra īconica{/it} "true image") from the given name {it}Veronica{/it}, borrowed from Late Greek {it}Berníkē, Beroníkē{/it}, name given in the Gospel of Nicodemus (ca. 4th century) to a woman subject to bleeding who is cured by Jesus (Matthew 9:20-22), in later tradition applied to a woman possessing an image of Jesus's face on a cloth

The names {it}Berníkē, Beroníkē{/it} are apparently variants of classical {it}Berenī́kē{/it}, borne by various Macedonian queens and princesses of the Ptolemaic dynasty in Egypt. The expected Latin adaptation would be {it}Veronīca{/it}, but this appears to be contradicted by modern Romance pronunciations of the name, with stress on the antepenult. Presumably stress has been adapted to names such as {it}Dominica{/it} formed with the unaccented suffix {it}-icus.{/it}
shortdef: an image of Christ's face said to have been impressed on the cloth that St. Veronica gave him to wipe his face with on the way to his crucifixion; also : a cloth resembling the legendary one of St. Veronica

quotes.t: Horses stand apart because of their {qword}versatile{/qword} roles in human society, which came to include dairy production, transportation, haulage, plowing, sports, warfare, religion, and status.

This year's Nobel Prize in Chemistry went to three scientists for their work on a {qword}versatile{/qword} strategy for synthesizing all manner of novel chemical compounds in an environmentally friendly way.  … The three scientists focused on a reaction called metathesis …
Linemen have to be nimble, corners physical and linebackers {qword}versatile{/qword}.

Adobos are the Philippines' most beloved, and most {qword}versatile{/qword}, dishes. They consist of meat, poultry, fish, or vegetables (such as okra and eggplant) slow-cooked in an aromatic broth of vinegar or coconut milk, garlic, black pepper, bay leaves, and, sometimes, soy sauce until virtually all the liquid has evaporated.

Within weeks [Gerd] Binnig, then 38 and with an infant daughter, worked with a colleague to build a prototype for what has become one of the most {qword}versatile{/qword} scientific tools ever created: the atomic force microscope, or AFM.

et: borrowed from Latin {it}versātilis{/it} "able to turn, operated by turning, capable of turning to different tasks," from {it}versāre{/it} "to keep turning" (frequentative of {it}vertere{/it} "to turn") + {it}-tilis{/it}, suffix with the sense "characterized by, obtained by" {ma}{mat|worth:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: embracing a variety of subjects, fields, or skills; also : turning with ease from one thing to another
having many uses or applications
changing or fluctuating readily : variable

pt: {sc}annoy{/sc} {sc}vex{/sc} {sc}irk{/sc} {sc}bother{/sc} mean to upset a person's composure. {sc}annoy{/sc} implies a wearing on the nerves by persistent petty unpleasantness.
{sc}vex{/sc} implies greater provocation and stronger disturbance and usually connotes anger but sometimes perplexity or anxiety.

pt.t: {it}vexed{/it} by her son's failure to clean his room

pt: {sc}irk{/sc} stresses difficulty in enduring and the resulting weariness or impatience of spirit.
{sc}bother{/sc} suggests interference with comfort or peace of mind.

quotes.t: The departure point for a {qword}viable{/qword} peace deal—either with Syria or the Palestinians—must not be based purely on what the political traffic in Israel will bear, but on the requirements of all sides.

As gene therapy begins to enjoy some preliminary successes, scientists at the World Anti-Doping Agency, which oversees drug testing for the Olympics, have started to worry that dopers might now see abuse of gene therapy in sport as a {qword}viable{/qword} option, though the practice was banned by WADA in 2003.

Under today's forest management practices, few trees die natural deaths and fewer still attain the girth of the old-growth trees that supported the ivory-bill. The sad fact is that there is really no place in the United States today where a {qword}viable{/qword} population of ivory-bills could persist even if captive reared birds were on hand to stock a release program.

Another truth is that corks expire with age. A few wineries recognize that fact and recork their library wines every 25 years or so, but that's not a {qword}viable{/qword} process for most collectors.

To ponder [John] Updike's work in now old-fashioned sociopolitical terms, it might be said that he examines our struggle to maintain a {qword}viable{/qword} center for our inner life while enduring the most revolutionary force in history—American capitalism.

At stake is the survival of our civilization and the habitability of the Earth. Or, as one eminent scientist put it, the pending question is whether the combination of an opposable thumb and a neocortex is a {qword}viable{/qword} combination on this planet.

When a patient agrees to forego a bed at the Portland VA—so far 75% of {qword}viable{/qword} candidates have agreed to do so—a small "strike force" swings into action. The patient is sent home, typically with various medicines, oxygen tanks, and sometimes, a mobile X-ray machine. A nurse visits every day to perform tests, provide IV infusions and monitor medications. As a backup, a physician is on 24-hour standby for emergencies.

pt: {sc}swing{/sc} {sc}sway{/sc} {sc}oscillate{/sc} {sc}vibrate{/sc} {sc}fluctuate{/sc} {sc}waver{/sc} {sc}undulate{/sc} mean to move from one direction to its opposite. {sc}swing{/sc} implies a movement of something attached at one end or one side.
{sc}sway{/sc} implies a slow swinging or teetering movement.
{sc}oscillate{/sc} stresses a usually regular alternation of direction.
{sc}vibrate{/sc} suggests the rapid oscillation of an elastic body under stress or impact.
{sc}fluctuate{/sc} suggests constant irregular changes of level, intensity, or value.
{sc}waver{/sc} stresses irregular motion suggestive of reeling or tottering.

pt: {sc}swing{/sc} {sc}sway{/sc} {sc}oscillate{/sc} {sc}vibrate{/sc} {sc}fluctuate{/sc} {sc}waver{/sc} {sc}undulate{/sc} mean to move from one direction to its opposite. {sc}swing{/sc} implies a movement of something attached at one end or one side.
{sc}sway{/sc} implies a slow swinging or teetering movement.
{sc}oscillate{/sc} stresses a usually regular alternation of direction.
{sc}vibrate{/sc} suggests the rapid oscillation of an elastic body under stress or impact.
{sc}fluctuate{/sc} suggests constant irregular changes of level, intensity, or value.
{sc}waver{/sc} stresses irregular motion suggestive of reeling or tottering.

to mark or measure by oscillation

dt.t: {wi}vicarious{/wi} menstruation manifested by bleeding from the nose

quotes.t: I am a {qword}vicarious{/qword} eater, often preferring a description of a meal to eating it. I hoard the Wednesday food section of the {it}New York Times{/it}, savoring it as my late-night reading, finishing always with the restaurant review.
Most people caged in the humdrum routines of modern life are eager for {qword}vicarious{/qword} glimpses of pain, joy, and especially vitality.

There is an immense sub-middle class with enough money to preserve it from rancorous envy of the rich, but not enough to preserve it from boredom; it needs {qword}vicarious{/qword} compensations and manages to find them in the gossip columns.
To give himself the {qword}vicarious{/qword} illusion of companionship, he fell back on letters.

By means of ferocious jokes … he could vent his hatred of pioneer life and all its conditions, those conditions that were thwarting his creative life; he could, in this {qword}vicarious{/qword} manner, appease the artist in him …

shortdef: experienced or realized through imaginative or sympathetic participation in the experience of another

pt: {sc}fault{/sc} {sc}failing{/sc} {sc}frailty{/sc} {sc}foible{/sc} {sc}vice{/sc} mean an imperfection or weakness of character. {sc}fault{/sc} implies a failure, not necessarily culpable, to reach some standard of perfection in disposition, action, or habit.

pt.t: a writer of many virtues and few {it}faults{/it}

pt: {sc}failing{/sc} suggests a minor shortcoming in character.

pt.t: being late is a {it}failing{/it} of mine

pt: {sc}frailty{/sc} implies a general or chronic proneness to yield to temptation.
{sc}foible{/sc} applies to a harmless or endearing weakness or idiosyncrasy.
{sc}vice{/sc} can be a general term for any imperfection or weakness, but it often suggests violation of a moral code or the giving of offense to the moral sensibilities of others.
{sc}offense{/sc} {sc}sin{/sc} {sc}vice{/sc} {sc}crime{/sc} {sc}scandal{/sc} mean a transgression of law. {sc}offense{/sc} applies to the infraction of any law, rule, or code.

pt.t: at that school no {it}offense{/it} went unpunished

pt: {sc}sin{/sc} implies an offense against moral or religious law.
{sc}vice{/sc} applies to a habit or practice that degrades or corrupts.
{sc}crime{/sc} implies a serious offense punishable by the law of the state.
{sc}scandal{/sc} applies to an offense that outrages the public conscience.

pt.t: a career ruined by a sex {it}scandal{/it}

pt: {sc}fault{/sc} {sc}failing{/sc} {sc}frailty{/sc} {sc}foible{/sc} {sc}vice{/sc} mean an imperfection or weakness of character. {sc}fault{/sc} implies a failure, not necessarily culpable, to reach some standard of perfection in disposition, action, or habit.

pt.t: a writer of many virtues and few {it}faults{/it}

pt: {sc}failing{/sc} suggests a minor shortcoming in character.

pt.t: being late is a {it}failing{/it} of mine

pt: {sc}frailty{/sc} implies a general or chronic proneness to yield to temptation.
{sc}foible{/sc} applies to a harmless or endearing weakness or idiosyncrasy.
{sc}vice{/sc} can be a general term for any imperfection or weakness, but it often suggests violation of a moral code or the giving of offense to the moral sensibilities of others.
{sc}offense{/sc} {sc}sin{/sc} {sc}vice{/sc} {sc}crime{/sc} {sc}scandal{/sc} mean a transgression of law. {sc}offense{/sc} applies to the infraction of any law, rule, or code.

pt.t: at that school no {it}offense{/it} went unpunished

pt: {sc}sin{/sc} implies an offense against moral or religious law.
{sc}vice{/sc} applies to a habit or practice that degrades or corrupts.
{sc}crime{/sc} implies a serious offense punishable by the law of the state.
{sc}scandal{/sc} applies to an offense that outrages the public conscience.

pt.t: a career ruined by a sex {it}scandal{/it}

pt: {sc}vicious{/sc} {sc}villainous{/sc} {sc}iniquitous{/sc} {sc}nefarious{/sc} {sc}corrupt{/sc} {sc}degenerate{/sc} mean highly reprehensible or offensive in character, nature, or conduct. {sc}vicious{/sc} may directly oppose {it}virtuous{/it} in implying moral depravity, or may connote malignancy, cruelty, or destructive violence.
{sc}villainous{/sc} applies to any evil, depraved, or vile conduct or characteristic.
{sc}iniquitous{/sc} implies absence of all signs of justice or fairness.
{sc}nefarious{/sc} suggests flagrant breaching of time-honored laws and traditions of conduct.
{sc}corrupt{/sc} stresses a loss of moral integrity or probity causing betrayal of principle or sworn obligations.

pt.t: city hall was rife with {it}corrupt{/it} politicians

pt: {sc}degenerate{/sc} suggests having sunk to an especially vicious or enervated condition.

pt.t: a {it}degenerate{/it} regime propped up by foreign powers

quotes.t: The genetically {qword}vicious{/qword} nature of presidential campaigns in America is too obvious to argue with, but some people call it fun, and I am one of them.
The Olympics always seemed too much like war, {qword}vicious{/qword} old men manipulating youngsters hungry for fame into performing heroic acts for short change.
Challenging areas of social consensus, however dumb or even {qword}vicious{/qword} the consensus, is largely off limits for the media, because it wins no friends among the general public.
True to Finals form, this hardwood battle has become as {qword}vicious{/qword} as any street scrum.

For most of my life I have retained a haunting image from an old Tarzan movie: piranhas, those {qword}vicious{/qword} little fish with the arrowhead-shaped teeth, devouring a pig. Forget that there are no piranha in Africa. But they do exist in Brazil, in abundance in the meandering waterways of the Amazon Basin.
His slider—a {qword}vicious{/qword}, hard-breaking pitch with which he finished off right-handed hitters for years—was inconsistent and benign, and the velocity of his fastball was diminished.

pt: {sc}exculpate{/sc} {sc}absolve{/sc} {sc}exonerate{/sc} {sc}acquit{/sc} {sc}vindicate{/sc} mean to free from a charge. {sc}exculpate{/sc} implies a clearing from blame or fault often in a matter of small importance.

pt.t: {it}exculpating{/it} himself from the charge of overenthusiasm

pt: {sc}absolve{/sc} implies a release either from an obligation that binds the conscience or from the consequences of disobeying the law or committing a sin.
{sc}exonerate{/sc} implies a complete clearance from an accusation or charge and from any attendant suspicion of blame or guilt.
{sc}acquit{/sc} implies a formal decision in one's favor with respect to a definite charge.

{sc}vindicate{/sc} may refer to things as well as persons that have been subjected to critical attack or imputation of guilt, weakness, or folly, and implies a clearing effected by proving the unfairness of such criticism or blame.
{sc}maintain{/sc} {sc}assert{/sc} {sc}defend{/sc} {sc}vindicate{/sc} {sc}justify{/sc} mean to uphold as true, right, just, or reasonable. {sc}maintain{/sc} stresses firmness of conviction.
{sc}assert{/sc} suggests determination to make others accept one's claim.
{sc}defend{/sc} implies maintaining in the face of attack or criticism.

pt.t: his success {it}vindicated{/it} our faith in him

pt: {sc}justify{/sc} implies showing to be true, just, or valid by appeal to a standard or to precedent.

pt.t: the action was used to {it}justify{/it} military intervention

et: Latin {it}vindicatus{/it}, past participle of {it}vindicare{/it} to lay claim to, avenge, from {it}vindic-, vindex{/it} claimant, avenger
shortdef: to free from allegation or blame
confirm, substantiate
to provide justification or defense for : justify

dt: {bc}a person or thing that {d_link|vindicates|vindicate} something or someone

dt.t: They saw George, who had served with distinction against France in the War of the Spanish Succession, as a British warrior king, the {wi}vindicator{/wi} of European Protestantism, and thus the defender of the balance of power.
They falsely have cast themselves as the defender of rights and {wi}vindicator{/wi} of the vulnerable.

John Quincy Adams expressed this view definitively when he remarked that the United States "goes not abroad in search of monsters to destroy. She is the well-wisher to the freedom and independence of all. She is the champion and {wi}vindicator{/wi} only of her own."

shortdef: a person or thing that vindicates something or someone

dt: {bc}a person or thing that {d_link|vindicates|vindicate} something or someone

providing vindication : justificatory
punitive, retributive

quotes.t: Well, maybe actually waging vendettas is a bad idea, but to be known for your vindictiveness can be a great advantage, for then people will take care not to cross you. And maybe the surest way of acquiring a reputation for vindictiveness is actually to be {qword}vindictive{/qword}.
It is not true that suffering ennobles the character; happiness does that sometimes, but suffering, for the most part, makes men petty and {qword}vindictive{/qword}.

In observing so long a silence I have been influenced much more by a {qword}vindictive{/qword} purpose,—a purpose to punish you for your suspicion that I could possibly feel myself hurt or offended by any critical suggestion of yours …

subsource.source: in {it}William Cowper's Letters{/it}, Edward Verrall Lucas, editor

quotes.t: And though his [John Simon's] caustic wit can sometimes sound more personally {qword}vindictive{/qword} than objectively critical, it allows him to plow through a lot of literary pretentiousness.

The bear, seen in many aspects as humanlike, was subject to ambivalent attitudes: mainly, he was seen as a stand-in for benevolent supernaturals, but sometimes also as a dangerous and at times a {qword}vindictive{/qword} and harmful one.
A machine gun lashed at him from across the river.  … In the darkness, it spat a {qword}vindictive{/qword} white light like an acetylene torch, and its sound was terrifying.

shortdef: disposed to seek revenge : vengeful
intended for or involving revenge
intended to cause anguish or hurt : spiteful

quotes.t: And though his [John Simon's] caustic wit can sometimes sound more personally {qword}vindictive{/qword} than objectively critical, it allows him to plow through a lot of literary pretentiousness.

The bear, seen in many aspects as humanlike, was subject to ambivalent attitudes: mainly, he was seen as a stand-in for benevolent supernaturals, but sometimes also as a dangerous and at times a {qword}vindictive{/qword} and harmful one.
A machine gun lashed at him from across the river.  … In the darkness, it spat a {qword}vindictive{/qword} white light like an acetylene torch, and its sound was terrifying.

quotes.t: Well, maybe actually waging vendettas is a bad idea, but to be known for your vindictiveness can be a great advantage, for then people will take care not to cross you. And maybe the surest way of acquiring a reputation for vindictiveness is actually to be {qword}vindictive{/qword}.
It is not true that suffering ennobles the character; happiness does that sometimes, but suffering, for the most part, makes men petty and {qword}vindictive{/qword}.

dt: {bc}a bowed stringed instrument chiefly of the 16th and 17th centuries made in treble, alto, tenor, and bass sizes and distinguished from members of the {a_link|violin} family especially in having a deep body, a flat back, sloping shoulders, usually six strings, a fretted fingerboard, and a low-arched bridge

et: Middle English {it}vial,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}viel, viele, viole,{/it} corresponding to continental Old French {it}viele{/it} (by suffix substitution {it}vielle{/it}) and {it}viole,{/it} from a Gallo-Romance base {it}vi-,{/it} attested earliest in Old Occitan {it}viola, viula{/it} "viol," of uncertain origin

It has been claimed that the base {it}vi-{/it} is of onomatopoeic origin, originally in verbal derivatives (Old French {it}vieller,{/it} Old Occitan {it}violar{/it} "to play a stringed instrument"), from which the noun designating the instrument is derived. However, it is unlikely that the resemblance between the {it}viola{/it} words and Germanic {it}*fiþlō-{/it} (whence Old High German {it}fidula,{/it} Old English {it}*fiðele{/it}; see {et_link|fiddle:1|fiddle:1}), a noun probably designating a string instrument, is pure chance, and borrowing from Germanic into Gallo-Romance seems more plausible than the reverse direction (despite the unexplained voicing of initial {it}f{/it}). Medieval Latin {it}vitula, vidula{/it} (best attested in English documents) are not necessarily indicative of an earlier Gallo-Romance form of {it}viola,{/it} as the Germanic etymon may have contaminated the Romance word. There is no likely relation between the Medieval Latin words and Latin {it}Vītula{/it} "goddess of joy," {it}vītulārī{/it} "to utter a cry of exultation," which should have developed quite differently in Romance.
shortdef: a bowed stringed instrument chiefly of the 16th and 17th centuries made in treble, alto, tenor, and bass sizes and distinguished from members of the violin family especially in having a deep body, a flat back, sloping shoulders, usually six strings, a fretted fingerboard, and a low-arched bridge

dt: {bc}a bowed stringed instrument chiefly of the 16th and 17th centuries made in treble, alto, tenor, and bass sizes and distinguished from members of the {a_link|violin} family especially in having a deep body, a flat back, sloping shoulders, usually six strings, a fretted fingerboard, and a low-arched bridge

et: Middle English {it}vial,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}viel, viele, viole,{/it} corresponding to continental Old French {it}viele{/it} (by suffix substitution {it}vielle{/it}) and {it}viole,{/it} from a Gallo-Romance base {it}vi-,{/it} attested earliest in Old Occitan {it}viola, viula{/it} "viol," of uncertain origin

It has been claimed that the base {it}vi-{/it} is of onomatopoeic origin, originally in verbal derivatives (Old French {it}vieller,{/it} Old Occitan {it}violar{/it} "to play a stringed instrument"), from which the noun designating the instrument is derived. However, it is unlikely that the resemblance between the {it}viola{/it} words and Germanic {it}*fiþlō-{/it} (whence Old High German {it}fidula,{/it} Old English {it}*fiðele{/it}; see {et_link|fiddle:1|fiddle:1}), a noun probably designating a string instrument, is pure chance, and borrowing from Germanic into Gallo-Romance seems more plausible than the reverse direction (despite the unexplained voicing of initial {it}f{/it}). Medieval Latin {it}vitula, vidula{/it} (best attested in English documents) are not necessarily indicative of an earlier Gallo-Romance form of {it}viola,{/it} as the Germanic etymon may have contaminated the Romance word. There is no likely relation between the Medieval Latin words and Latin {it}Vītula{/it} "goddess of joy," {it}vītulārī{/it} "to utter a cry of exultation," which should have developed quite differently in Romance.

dt.t: Recent advances in our knowledge about how HIV replicates sprang from new technology able to measure {phrase}viral load{/phrase}—the level of HIV—in the blood. … The higher a person's {wi}viral load{/wi}, the faster he or she gets sick.
In patients with a heavy hepatic {phrase}tumor load{/phrase}, liver transplantation may prolong useful life.
Over time the {phrase}worm load{/phrase} will damage the heart, shortening the dog's life.

dt: {bc}a preparation that is administered (as by injection) to stimulate the body's {d_link|immune response|immune response} against a specific infectious agent or disease: such as

{bc}an antigenic preparation of a typically inactivated or attenuated {dx_def}see {dxt|attenuated|attenuated|2}{/dx_def} pathogenic agent (such as a bacterium or virus) or one of its components or products (such as a protein or toxin)

dt.t: Many {wi}vaccines{/wi} are made from the virus itself, either weakened or killed, which will induce antibodies to bind and kill a live virus. Measles {wi}vaccines{/wi} are just that, weakened (or attenuated) measles viruses.
… a tetanus toxoid-containing {wi}vaccine{/wi} might be recommended for wound management in a pregnant woman if [greater than or equal to] 5 years have elapsed … .
In addition the subunit used in a {wi}vaccine{/wi} must be carefully chosen, because not all components of a pathogen represent beneficial immunological targets.

aq.auth: Thomas J. Matthews and Dani P. Bolognesi

dt: {bc}a preparation of genetic material (such as a strand of synthesized {d_link|messenger RNA|messenger RNA}) that is used by the cells of the body to produce an antigenic substance (such as a fragment of virus {d_link|spike protein|spike protein})

dt.t: … Moderna's coronavirus {wi}vaccine{/wi} … works by injecting a small piece of mRNA from the coronavirus that codes for the virus' spike protein. … {phrase}mRNA vaccine{/phrase} spurs the body to produce the spike protein internally. That, in turn, triggers an immune response.

The revolutionary {phrase}messenger RNA vaccines{/phrase} that are now available have been over a decade in development. … Messenger RNA enters the cell cytoplasm and produces protein from the spike of the Covid-19 virus.

Viral {phrase}vector vaccines{/phrase}, another recent type of {wi}vaccine{/wi}, are similar to DNA and RNA {wi}vaccines{/wi}, but the virus's genetic information is housed in an attenuated virus (unrelated to the disease-causing virus) that helps to promote host cell fusion and entry.

dt: Vaccines may contain {d_link|adjuvants|adjuvant:2} (such as aluminum hydroxide) designed to enhance the strength and duration of the body's immune response.
{bc}a preparation or immunotherapy that is used to stimulate the body's immune response against noninfectious substances, agents, or diseases

dt.t: The U.S. Army is also testing a ricin {wi}vaccine{/wi} and has reported success in mice.
… many of the most promising new cancer {wi}vaccines{/wi} use dendritic cells to train the immune system to recognize tumor cells.

et: earlier, "fluid from cowpox pustules used in inoculation," noun use of {it}vaccine{/it} "of cowpox" (in the phrases {it}vaccine disease, vaccine matter{/it}), borrowed from New Latin {it}vaccina{/it} (in {it}variolae vaccinae{/it} "cowpox"), going back to Latin, feminine of {it}vaccīnus{/it} "of or from a cow," from {it}vacca{/it} "cow" (perhaps akin to Sanskrit {it}vaśā{/it} "cow") + {it}-īnus{/it} {et_link|-ine:1|-ine:1}; in extended sense, "preparation of organisms administered to produce immunity," in part borrowed from French {it}vaccin{/it}, masculine derivative of {it}vaccine{/it} "cowpox, matter from cowpox pustules," borrowed from New Latin or English
shortdef: a preparation that is administered (as by injection) to stimulate the body's immune response against a specific infectious agent or disease: such as
