pt: {sc}moral{/sc} {sc}ethical{/sc} {sc}virtuous{/sc} {sc}righteous{/sc} {sc}noble{/sc} mean conforming to a standard of what is right and good. {sc}moral{/sc} implies conformity to established sanctioned codes or accepted notions of right and wrong.

pt.t: the basic {it}moral{/it} values of a community

pt: {sc}ethical{/sc} may suggest the involvement of more difficult or subtle questions of rightness, fairness, or equity.

pt.t: not a religious person, but {it}virtuous{/it} nevertheless

pt: {sc}righteous{/sc} stresses guiltlessness or blamelessness and often suggests the sanctimonious.

pt.t: wished to be {it}righteous{/it} before God and the world

pt: {sc}noble{/sc} implies moral eminence and freedom from anything petty, mean, or dubious in conduct and character.

pt.t: had the {it}noblest{/it} of reasons for seeking office

quotes.t: In a kind of {qword}virtuous{/qword} circle, the "second tier" schools got better as applications rose and they could become choosier in assembling a class—which in turn raised the quality of the whole experience on campus and made the school more attractive to both topflight professors and the next wave of applicants.

In its quest to create ice cream as voluptuous as butter and as {qword}virtuous{/qword} as broccoli, the ice cream industry has probed the depths of the Arctic Ocean, studied the intimate structures of algae and foisted numerous failures on the American public.

Children born into high-income households become part of a {qword}virtuous{/qword} circle of success. Parents with university degrees tend to earn more, set higher educational goals for their children, and invest more time in the children's schooling than parents who have a high-school education or less.

We redefined virtue as health. And considering the probable state of our souls, this was not a bad move. By relocating the seat of virtue from the soul to the pecs, the abs and the coronary arteries, we may not have become the most {qword}virtuous{/qword} people on earth, but we surely became the most desperate for grace. We spend $5 billion a year on our health-club memberships, $2 billion on vitamins, nearly $1 billion on home exercise equipment, and $6 billion on sneakers to wear out on our treadmills and StairMasters.

shortdef: having or exhibiting virtue
morally excellent : righteous
chaste

dt: {bc}a chain of events in which one desirable occurrence leads to another which further promotes the first occurrence and so on resulting in a continuous process of improvement

dt.t: But the economy is depressed, in large part, because of the housing bust, which immediately suggests the possibility of a {wi}virtuous circle{/wi}: an improving economy leads to a surge in home purchases, which leads to more construction, which strengthens the economy further, and so on.

shortdef: a chain of events in which one desirable occurrence leads to another which further promotes the first occurrence and so on resulting in a continuous process of improvement

pt: {sc}moral{/sc} {sc}ethical{/sc} {sc}virtuous{/sc} {sc}righteous{/sc} {sc}noble{/sc} mean conforming to a standard of what is right and good. {sc}moral{/sc} implies conformity to established sanctioned codes or accepted notions of right and wrong.

pt.t: the basic {it}moral{/it} values of a community

pt: {sc}ethical{/sc} may suggest the involvement of more difficult or subtle questions of rightness, fairness, or equity.

pt.t: not a religious person, but {it}virtuous{/it} nevertheless

pt: {sc}righteous{/sc} stresses guiltlessness or blamelessness and often suggests the sanctimonious.

pt.t: wished to be {it}righteous{/it} before God and the world

pt: {sc}noble{/sc} implies moral eminence and freedom from anything petty, mean, or dubious in conduct and character.

pt.t: had the {it}noblest{/it} of reasons for seeking office

quotes.t: In a kind of {qword}virtuous{/qword} circle, the "second tier" schools got better as applications rose and they could become choosier in assembling a class—which in turn raised the quality of the whole experience on campus and made the school more attractive to both topflight professors and the next wave of applicants.

In its quest to create ice cream as voluptuous as butter and as {qword}virtuous{/qword} as broccoli, the ice cream industry has probed the depths of the Arctic Ocean, studied the intimate structures of algae and foisted numerous failures on the American public.

Children born into high-income households become part of a {qword}virtuous{/qword} circle of success. Parents with university degrees tend to earn more, set higher educational goals for their children, and invest more time in the children's schooling than parents who have a high-school education or less.

We redefined virtue as health. And considering the probable state of our souls, this was not a bad move. By relocating the seat of virtue from the soul to the pecs, the abs and the coronary arteries, we may not have become the most {qword}virtuous{/qword} people on earth, but we surely became the most desperate for grace. We spend $5 billion a year on our health-club memberships, $2 billion on vitamins, nearly $1 billion on home exercise equipment, and $6 billion on sneakers to wear out on our treadmills and StairMasters.

shortdef: having or exhibiting virtue
morally excellent : righteous
chaste

dt: {bc}a computer program that is usually disguised as an innocuous program or file, that often produces copies of itself and inserts them into other programs, and that when run usually performs a malicious action (such as destroying data or damaging software)

et: Middle English, "pus, discharge from a sore, semen," borrowed from Latin {it}vīrus{/it} (neuter) "venom, poisonous fluid, acrid element in a substance, secretion with medical or magical properties," going back to an Indo-European base {it}*u̯is-/*u̯īs-{/it} "poison, venom," whence also Middle Irish {it}fí{/it} "venom, poison, evil," Greek {it}īós{/it} "poison," Tocharian A {it}wäs{/it} and Tocharian B {it}wase,{/it} Sanskrit {it}viṣáṃ,{/it} Avestan {it}viš, viša-{/it} (also {it}vīš{/it}?); (sense 1) borrowed from German, borrowed from Latin

The application of Latin {it}vīrus{/it} to the submicroscopic infectious agents now considered viruses (rather than to any infectious agent) was apparently first made by the Dutch microbiologist Martinus Beijerinck (1851-1931) in "Ueber ein Contagium vivum fluidum als Ursache der Fleckenkrankheit der Tabaksblätter," {it}Verhandelingen der Koninklijke Akademie van Wetenschappen te Amsterdam,{/it} Tweede Sectie, Deel VI, no. 5 (1898). Beijerinck, in studying tobacco mosaic virus, mistakenly believed that the agent was a fluid ({it}contagium vivum fluidum{/it}, "living fluid infection") because it passed through filters capable of trapping bacteria. — The neuter gender of {it}vīrus{/it} suggests that it was originally an s-stem; forms in text other than the nominative and accusative are perhaps found only in Lucretius. The length of the vowel in Latin, Irish, and Greek, in contrast to the short vowel in Tocharian and Indo-Iranian, has been variously accounted for. M. Mayrhofer ({it}Etymologisches Wörterbuch des Altindoarischen{/it}) suggests that the etymon was originally a root noun, {it}*u̯īs, *u̯is-ó-,{/it} with lengthening of the monosyllabic vowel; the daughter languages then generalized one or the other form.
shortdef: any of a large group of submicroscopic infectious agents that are usually regarded as nonliving extremely complex molecules, that typically contain a protein coat surrounding an RNA or DNA core of genetic material but no semipermeable membrane, that are capable of growth and multiplication only in living cells, and that cause various important diseases in humans, animals, and plants; also : filterable virus
a disease or illness caused by a virus
the causative agent of an infectious disease

hepatitis d virus

dt: {bc}any of several filoviruses (genus {it}Ebolavirus{/it} and especially species {it}Zaire ebolavirus{/it}) of African origin that cause an often fatal hemorrhagic fever

et: from the {it}Ebola{/it} River in the northern Democratic Republic of the Congo (former Zaire)

According to Peter Piot, a Belgian member of an international commission formed to investigate the first outbreak of the virus in 1976, the name was chosen by members of the commission (including the French physician Pierre Sureau and the Americans Karl Johnson and Joel Breman) from a map of Zaire at the Fonds Médical Tropical, a non-governmental organization in Kinshasa where the members were lodged. Though the Ebola River (a headwater stream of the Mongala River, a tributary of the Congo) turned out to be a considerable distance from the village of Yambuku where the fever was first observed, the name was nonetheless retained. The name "Yambuku virus" was avoided because of the stigma it would have attached to the village. (See Peter Piot, {it}No Time to Lose: A Life in Pursuit of Deadly Viruses,{/it} W.W. Norton, 2012, pp. 56-57.)
shortdef: any of several filoviruses (genus Ebolavirus and especially species Zaire ebolavirus) of African origin that cause an often fatal hemorrhagic fever
epstein-barr virus

dt.t: {wi}Coxsackieviruses{/wi} infect more than 20 million people annually in the United States and can cause illnesses ranging from a cold to an inflammation of the heart. However, most of the viruses are benign, so only about 10,000 infected people become ill.
{wi}Coxsackie viruses{/wi} are transmitted from one person to the next through respiratory droplets or from foods, hands or utensils contaminated with the virus.

quotes.t: One of the wonders of cooking is that the tiniest adjustment to what you are making, the addition of a single ingredient or the execution of a technique, can entirely change a dish and the {qword}visceral{/qword} response you get from eating it.

In 1972 he began an address at a Chamber of Commerce luncheon, "Let me start off by saying this is not quite an honor, my being here. I haven't had too much regard for the Chamber of Commerce in my years in Boston. When the Celtics won 11 championships in 13 years, it was ignored in their own town." Arnold Jacob Auerbach, though paradoxical and highly idiosyncratic, was foremost a direct and {qword}visceral{/qword} man.
When you measure your waist circumference, you're indirectly measuring your {qword}visceral{/qword} fat.

But there are strong taboos I haven't anticipated. The most striking is the {qword}visceral{/qword} dislike of rawness. In China, the consumption of raw foods was historically viewed as a barbarian habit, and most everything is still eaten cooked.

dt: {bc}a severe form of {d_link|leishmaniasis|leishmaniasis} that is marked by fever, weight loss, progressive anemia, {d_link|leukopenia|leukopenia}, and enlargement of the spleen and liver, is caused by a parasitic protozoan (as {it}Leishmania donovani{/it}) which proliferates in macrophages of the liver, spleen, and bone marrow, and is typically fatal if untreated

dt.t: The disease's deadly form, {wi}visceral leishmaniasis{/wi}, caused when the parasite takes up residence in the liver, spleen and bone marrow, kills about 40,000 people a year worldwide.

shortdef: a severe form of leishmaniasis that is marked by fever, weight loss, progressive anemia, leukopenia, and enlargement of the spleen and liver, is caused by a parasitic protozoan (as Leishmania donovani) which proliferates in macrophages of the liver, spleen, and bone marrow, and is typically fatal if untreated —called also kala-azar

pt: {sc}imaginary{/sc} {sc}fanciful{/sc} {sc}visionary{/sc} {sc}fantastic{/sc} {sc}chimerical{/sc} {sc}quixotic{/sc} mean unreal or unbelievable. {sc}imaginary{/sc} applies to something which is fictitious and purely the product of one's imagination.
{sc}fanciful{/sc} suggests the free play of the imagination.
{sc}visionary{/sc} stresses impracticality or incapability of realization.
{sc}fantastic{/sc} implies incredibility or strangeness beyond belief.
{sc}quixotic{/sc} implies a devotion to romantic or chivalrous ideals unrestrained by ordinary prudence and common sense.

et: borrowed from German {it}Rhodopsin,{/it} from {it}rhod-{/it} {et_link|rhod-|rhodo-} + Greek {it}ópsis{/it} "appearance, sight, vision" + German {it}-in{/it} {et_link|-in:1|-in:1} {ma}{mat|optic:1|}{/ma}

Term introduced by the German physiologist Wilhelm Kühne (1837-1900) and his assistant August Ewald (1849-1924) in "Untersuchungen über den Sehpurpur," {it}Untersuchungen aus dem Physiologischen Institute der Universität Heidelberg,{/it} 1. Band (1878), p. 181: "Was den Sehpurpur im Dunkel ändert, pflegt es z. Th. in derselben Weise zu thun, wie das Licht, d.h. erst eine gelbe Materie, dann farblose Substanz hervorzubringen. Der Kürze wegen und um dem Auslande unsere Bezeichnungen zugänglich zu machen, kann man sagen, Rhodopsin werde erst in Xanthopsin, dieses in Leukopsin zersetzt." ("Those things [i.e., reagents] that convert visual purple in darkness in part act in the same manner as light, that is, they first produce a yellow material, then a colorless substance. For the sake of brevity, and in order to make our designations more accessible to foreigners, we can say that rhodopsin is first broken down into xanthopsin ['visual yellow'], and this into leucopsin ['visual white'].") Kühne's selection of the combining element {it}rhod-,{/it} usually meaning "red," is somewhat idiosyncratic, given that he is rendering German {it}Sehpurpur{/it} ("visual purple") and not {it}Sehrot{/it} ("visual red").
shortdef: a red photosensitive pigment in the retinal rods of the eye of most vertebrates that is important in vision in dim light —called also visual purple

pt: {sc}essential{/sc} {sc}fundamental{/sc} {sc}vital{/sc} {sc}cardinal{/sc} mean so important as to be indispensable. {sc}essential{/sc} implies belonging to the very nature of a thing and therefore being incapable of removal without destroying the thing itself or its character.
{sc}fundamental{/sc} applies to something that is a foundation without which an entire system or complex whole would collapse.
{sc}vital{/sc} suggests something that is necessary to a thing's continued existence or operation.
{sc}cardinal{/sc} suggests something on which an outcome turns or depends.

pt: {sc}essential{/sc} {sc}fundamental{/sc} {sc}vital{/sc} {sc}cardinal{/sc} mean so important as to be indispensable. {sc}essential{/sc} implies belonging to the very nature of a thing and therefore being incapable of removal without destroying the thing itself or its character.
{sc}fundamental{/sc} applies to something that is a foundation without which an entire system or complex whole would collapse.
{sc}vital{/sc} suggests something that is necessary to a thing's continued existence or operation.
{sc}cardinal{/sc} suggests something on which an outcome turns or depends.

fundamentally concerned with or affecting life or living beings: such as
tending to renew or refresh the living : invigorating

We take our drinks and pens to a table and slowly start getting to know each other. In fact, it takes all of 10 minutes to get his {wi}vitals{/wi} in writing (surgeon, 33, Yale, lives uptown) …
Look past … Bryant McKinni's mind-boggling vitals (6'8", 343) and focus on one number: 0. That's how many sacks he surrendered in his college career.
The nurse who came in most afternoons to check his {wi}vitals{/wi} and most evenings to get him ready for the night …

pt: {sc}lively{/sc} {sc}animated{/sc} {sc}vivacious{/sc} {sc}sprightly{/sc} {sc}gay{/sc} mean keenly alive and spirited. {sc}lively{/sc} suggests briskness, alertness, or energy.
{sc}animated{/sc} applies to what is spirited and active.
{sc}vivacious{/sc} suggests an activeness of gesture and wit, often playful or alluring.
{sc}sprightly{/sc} suggests lightness and spirited vigor of manner or wit.
{sc}gay{/sc} stresses complete freedom from care and overflowing spirits.

pt.t: the {it}gay{/it} spirit of Paris in the 1920s

quotes.t: Historically, in nations where city economies are dying and where, as well, cities are drained in service to transactions of decline, one city remains {qword}vivacious{/qword} longest: the capital city.

She could follow every word that the ramblers uttered. They were talking no secrets. They were merely indulging in the ordinary {qword}vivacious{/qword} chat of relatives who have long been parted in person though not in soul.

You see, for years I have built my figure on the premise that "fat people are jolly." I have eaten my way through: pleasant, cheery, sunny, smiling, gay, spirited, chipper, {qword}vivacious{/qword}, sparkling, happy, and sportive and was well on my way to becoming hysterical.

pt: {sc}vociferous{/sc} {sc}clamorous{/sc} {sc}blatant{/sc} {sc}strident{/sc} {sc}boisterous{/sc} {sc}obstreperous{/sc} mean so loud or insistent as to compel attention. {sc}vociferous{/sc} implies a vehement shouting or calling out.
{sc}clamorous{/sc} may imply insistency as well as vociferousness in demanding or protesting.
{sc}blatant{/sc} implies an offensive bellowing or insensitive loudness.

pt: {sc}boisterous{/sc} suggests a noisiness and turbulence due to high spirits.
{sc}obstreperous{/sc} suggests unruly and aggressive noisiness and resistance to restraint.

pt: {sc}fashion{/sc} {sc}style{/sc} {sc}mode{/sc} {sc}vogue{/sc} {sc}fad{/sc} {sc}rage{/sc} {sc}craze{/sc} mean the usage accepted by those who want to be up-to-date. {sc}fashion{/sc} is the most general term and applies to any way of dressing, behaving, writing, or performing that is favored at any one time or place.
{sc}style{/sc} often implies a distinctive fashion adopted by people of taste.

pt.t: a media baron used to traveling in {it}style{/it}

pt.t: slim bodies are the {it}mode{/it} at this resort

{sc}fad{/sc} suggests caprice in taking up or in dropping a fashion.
{sc}rage{/sc} and {sc}craze{/sc} stress intense enthusiasm in adopting a fad.

pt.t: Cajun food was the {it}rage{/it} nearly everywhere for a time
crossword puzzles once seemed just a passing {it}craze{/it} but have lasted

pt: {sc}express{/sc} {sc}vent{/sc} {sc}utter{/sc} {sc}voice{/sc} {sc}broach{/sc} {sc}air{/sc} mean to make known what one thinks or feels. {sc}express{/sc} suggests an impulse to reveal in words, gestures, actions, or what one creates or produces.
{sc}vent{/sc} stresses a strong inner compulsion to express especially in words.
{sc}utter{/sc} implies the use of the voice not necessarily in articulate speech.
{sc}voice{/sc} does not necessarily imply vocal utterance but does imply expression or formulation in words.
{sc}broach{/sc} adds the implication of disclosing for the first time something long thought over or reserved for a suitable occasion.
{sc}air{/sc} implies an exposing or parading of one's views often in order to gain relief or sympathy or attention.

{sc}vent{/sc} stresses a strong inner compulsion to express especially in words.

{sc}voice{/sc} does not necessarily imply vocal utterance but does imply expression or formulation in words.
{sc}broach{/sc} adds the implication of disclosing for the first time something long thought over or reserved for a suitable occasion.
{sc}air{/sc} implies an exposing or parading of one's views often in order to gain relief or sympathy or attention.

pt: {sc}talkative{/sc} {sc}loquacious{/sc} {sc}garrulous{/sc} {sc}voluble{/sc} mean given to talk or talking. {sc}talkative{/sc} may imply a readiness to engage in talk or a disposition to enjoy conversation.
{sc}loquacious{/sc} suggests the power of expressing oneself articulately, fluently, or glibly.
{sc}garrulous{/sc} implies prosy, rambling, or tedious loquacity.
{sc}voluble{/sc} suggests a free, easy, and unending loquacity.

et: Middle English {it}volible, voluble{/it} "able to turn, changing," borrowed from Latin {it}volūbilis{/it} "turning on its axis, rolling, flowing, (of speech) readily flowing, fluent," from {it}volū-,{/it} variant stem of {it}volvere{/it} "to set in a circular course, cause to roll" + {it}-bilis{/it} "capable (of acting) or worthy (of being acted upon)" {ma}{mat|wallow:1|}, {mat|-able|}{/ma}
shortdef: easily rolling or turning : rotating
characterized by ready or rapid speech : glib, fluent

{sc}willing{/sc} implies a readiness and eagerness to accede to or anticipate the wishes of another.

pt: {sc}sensuous{/sc} {sc}sensual{/sc} {sc}luxurious{/sc} {sc}voluptuous{/sc} mean relating to or providing pleasure through gratification of the senses. {sc}sensuous{/sc} implies gratification of the senses for the sake of aesthetic pleasure.
{sc}sensual{/sc} tends to imply the gratification of the senses or the indulgence of the physical appetites as ends in themselves.
{sc}luxurious{/sc} suggests the indulgence of sensuous pleasure inducing bodily ease and languor.
{sc}voluptuous{/sc} implies more strongly an abandonment especially to sensual pleasure.

dt: {bc}an unusually large number of debates and votes that happen in one day on a single piece of legislation to which an unlimited number of amendments can be introduced, debated, and voted on

dt.t: The Senate defines it as 15 or more votes that happen on a piece of legislation in a single day (while {wi}vote-a-ramas{/wi} are often done on budget resolutions, they can be about any piece of legislation, like the health care bill). After the allotted time of debate on a bill expires, any senator can introduce an unlimited number of amendments to a piece of legislation. They then vote on the amendments, marathon-style. This can go on for hours.

Passing a budget resolution is part of a process known as reconciliation, which allows legislation to pass in the Senate with only a simple majority instead of the typical 60-vote threshold, meaning Democrats would be able to green-light it without any Republican votes. But Republicans forced Democrats to go on the record with a series of votes on a slew of amendments in the politically painful "{wi}vote-a-rama{/wi}."

shortdef: an unusually large number of debates and votes that happen in one day on a single piece of legislation to which an unlimited number of amendments can be introduced, debated, and voted on

pt: {sc}award{/sc} implies giving what is deserved or merited usually after a careful weighing of pertinent factors.

shortdef: someone who obtains sexual gratification from observing unsuspecting individuals who are partly undressed, naked, or engaged in sexual acts; broadly : someone who habitually seeks sexual stimulation by visual means

dt: {bc}the desires or behavior of a {d_link|voyeur|voyeur}: such as
{bc}the practice of obtaining sexual gratification from observing others

dt.t: Psychiatrists generally divide {d_link|paraphilias|paraphilia} into two groups: those focused on objects, like a foot fetish, and those focused on behaviors, like exhibitionism, {wi}voyeurism{/wi} or {d_link|frottage|frottage} …

Ward, if he was guilty of anything at all, was guilty of observation. Looking, or (if you will) leering and ogling are not normally considered indictable offenses in British courts of law, but they do shade over into {wi}voyeurism{/wi} …

dt: {bc}the criminal act of surreptitiously viewing a person without their consent in a place where the person has a reasonable expectation of privacy (such as a home or public bathroom) or of using a device (such as a camera) for the purpose of such viewing

dt.t: A 21-year-old man has been charged with {wi}voyeurism{/wi} for allegedly using his phone's camera to view the person using the restroom in the stall next to him in a dorm on the Notre Dame campus, according to court records.

dt: {bc}the practice of taking pleasure in observing something private, sordid, or scandalous

dt.t: Now there's a volume for those who are … bored by the salacious {wi}voyeurism{/wi} of tell-alls.
{wi}Voyeurism{/wi} allows us to experience all the excitement of disaster, catastrophe, and pain, to witness the most horrible human events, without any danger of feeling real pain.
But the voice of the diarist … will always exert a fascination close to {wi}voyeurism{/wi}.

shortdef: the desires or behavior of a voyeur: such as

the practice of obtaining sexual gratification from observing others; also : the criminal act of surreptitiously viewing a person without their consent in a place where the person has a reasonable expectation of privacy (such as a home or public bathroom) or of using a device (such as a camera) for the purpose of such viewing
the practice of taking pleasure in observing something private, sordid, or scandalous

dt: {bc}of, relating to, or having the characteristics of a {d_link|voyeur|voyeur}

dt.t: … confronting her beauty gave him a bad conscience and made him feel shamefully {wi}voyeuristic{/wi} …
Through the video surveillance system, Polly engages in {wi}voyeuristic{/wi} eavesdropping.
… to demonstrate that the {wi}voyeuristic{/wi} thrill of watching a stripper ceases at the moment of nakedness.

utxt.t: In that film, the cameras {wi}voyeuristically{/wi} followed actor Richard Gere as he worked out and dressed up.

dt.t: As more employees connect to their office networks from home, they expose the company to attack. A {wi}VPN{/wi} lets companies use the Internet as a secure pathway into their existing network.

{wi}VPNs{/wi} help cloak your browsing information from your internet provider. When you use {wi}VPN{/wi} software, your device connects to a {wi}VPN{/wi} provider's servers. That way, all your web traffic passes through the {wi}VPN{/wi} provider's internet connection.

pt: {sc}common{/sc} {sc}ordinary{/sc} {sc}plain{/sc} {sc}familiar{/sc} {sc}popular{/sc} {sc}vulgar{/sc} mean generally met with and not in any way special, strange, or unusual. {sc}common{/sc} implies usual everyday quality or frequency of occurrence
and may additionally suggest inferiority or coarseness.
{sc}ordinary{/sc} stresses conformance in quality or kind with the regular order of things.
{sc}plain{/sc} is likely to suggest homely simplicity.
{sc}familiar{/sc} stresses the fact of being generally known and easily recognized.
{sc}popular{/sc} applies to what is accepted by or prevalent among people in general sometimes in contrast to upper classes or special groups.
{sc}vulgar{/sc}, otherwise similar to {sc}popular{/sc}, is likely to carry derogatory connotations (as of inferiority or coarseness).

pt.t: souvenirs designed to appeal to the {it}vulgar{/it} taste

pt: {sc}coarse{/sc} {sc}vulgar{/sc} {sc}gross{/sc} {sc}obscene{/sc} {sc}ribald{/sc} mean offensive to good taste or morals. {sc}coarse{/sc} implies roughness, rudeness, or crudeness of spirit, behavior, or language.

pt.t: found the {it}coarse{/it} humor of coworkers offensive

pt: {sc}obscene{/sc} applies to anything strongly repulsive to the sense of decency and propriety especially in sexual matters.

pt.t: {it}obscene{/it} language not allowed on the air

pt: {sc}ribald{/sc} applies to what is amusingly or picturesquely vulgar or irreverent or mildly indecent.

pt.t: entertained the campers with {it}ribald{/it} folk songs

dt: {bc}a form of venture capitalism in which aggressive methods are used to buy a distressed business with the intention of selling it at a profit

dt.t: But the real reason that Toys R Us has failed is (wait for it) {wi}vulture capitalism{/wi}, as the chain's Wall Street owners … borrowed way too much money to make its 2004 purchase happen, leaving the retailer in a lurch when sales stagnated.

utxt.t: For the time being, the charge that Mitt Romney is a "{wi}vulture capitalist{/wi}" for his work at Bain Capital has quieted down—Rick Perry, who coined the term, dropped out of the Republican primary last month, and Newt Gingrich, who did so much to amplify it, has fallen on hard times.

shortdef: a form of venture capitalism in which aggressive methods are used to buy a distressed business with the intention of selling it at a profit
